summary: The document is a declassified intelligence report from the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992, focusing on Antonio Abasolo Garcia, a Cuban industrial engineer with connections to Ernesto 'Che' Guevara and the Soviet Union. It outlines his professional engagements in Cuba's industries, his personal life, including a trip to Mexico to see his children, and his political affiliations. The report also highlights intelligence surveillance on Antonio's potential disillusionment with the Cuban regime and his plans to leave Cuba, alongside mentions of his anti-Castro brother, Gustavo Abasolo, living in Mexico, and a Soviet-sponsored submarine base in Cuba.
key_findings: Antonio Abasolo Garcia is a Cuban industrial engineer with ties to Che Guevara and the Soviet Union.
He was involved in various industries in Cuba, including wood furniture, paper, and toys, and had contacts with the Soviets regarding cement procurement.
Antonio traveled to Mexico in August 1963 on a special passport to see his children but was prevented from contacting them by his ex-wife.
His brother, Gustavo Abasolo, is strongly anti-Castro and has been living in Mexico since leaving Cuba around 1959 or 1960.
The document suggests intelligence interest in Antonio's potential disillusionment with the Cuban regime and his plans to leave Cuba.
There is mention of a submarine base in Cuba believed to be sponsored by the Soviets.
